titleStmt.title: Prognostic impact of diastolic dysfunction in systolic heart failure-A cross-project analysis from the German Competence Network Heart Failure

affiliation.orgName: and Department of Internal Medicine Cardiology

analytic.title: Prognostic impact of diastolic dysfunction in systolic heart failure-A cross-project analysis from the German Competence Network Heart Failure

biblStruct.note: Received: 4 December 2016 Revised: 27 February 2017 Accepted: 28 February 2017

application.desc: GROBID - A machine learning software for extracting information from scholarly documents

keywords.term: Heart Failure With Preserved Ejection Fraction
Heart Failure With Reduced Ejection Fraction

p.s: Background: We investigated the modifying role and prognostic importance of diastolic dysfunction (DD) in patients with heart failure and systolic dysfunction (SD).
The echocardiographic evaluation of diastolic function in patients with SD provides further prognostic information.

Methods: From the German Competence Network Heart Failure, 1046 heart failure patients with reduced left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF; <50%) were echocardiographically studied and followed for a median of 5 years.
SD was subdivided into nonsevere (LVEF 36%-49%) and severe (LVEF ≤35%); DD was subdivided into nonsevere (E/E 0 <15) and severe (E/E 0 ≥15).

Results: In general, severe SD was associated with higher hazard ratios (HRs; 2-fold to 3.5-fold) for all endpoints (all-cause death, cardiac death, cardiovascular hospitalization, duration of hospitalization).
Patients with severe SD had a 2.5-fold risk of death (95% confidence interval [CI]:
P < 0.001), and patients with severe DD showed a 1.8-fold risk (95% CI: 1.17-2.61,
Furthermore, we observed a strong interaction of SD and DD: concomitant severe DD in patients with moderate SD increased risk substantially (HR: 1.73, 95% CI: 1.16-2.6,
P = 0.007); by contrast, in patients with severe SD, additional presence of severe DD added little or no risk (HR for interaction: 0.5-1.2).
In heart failure patients with reduced LVEF, the evaluation of diastolic function provides additional prognostic information.

Although severe SD generally increased the risk for all endpoints, the degree of DD and its impact as a prognostic marker for overall and cardiovascular mortality appeared of particular relevance in subjects with nonsevere SD.
HFrEF. 8 The landmark report of Owan et al found that prognosis in patients with HFpEF is only slightly less grave than in patients with with HFrEF. 9

However, there is an ongoing discussion whether DD in HFrEF should be regarded as a pathophysiological factor on its own right, which autonomously contributes to disease progression, or rather as a precursor or sequel occurring in the context of SD.
An HFpEF paradigm introduced by Paulus and Tschöpe in 2013 proposes to include comorbidities, plasma markers of inflammation, and vascular response into diagnostic algorithms.
Of importance, this aims at restoring myocardial protein kinase C activity.
Substantially, myocardial remodeling in HFpEF differs from HFrEF, in which remodeling is driven by loss of cardiomyocytes. 10,11
Echocardiographic algorithms that should be employed to diagnose DD in healthy and diseased persons are still under debate, as are their diagnostic and therapeutic implications.

Currently, in subjects with normal left ventricular ejection fraction (LVEF), the ratio of early transmitral spectral Doppler velocity to early tissue Doppler mitral annular velocity (E/e 0 ratio) is recommended as the initial step for estimation of LV filling pressures; whereas in patients with reduced LVEF, mitral inflow velocities may be used first. 12
e current study aimed to investigate the prognostic utility of the mutual contribution of SD and DD to prognosis in patients with HFrEF.
This retrospective cohort study investigated patients included in follow-up studies performed within the German Competence Network Heart Failure (CNHF), as previously described.

The CNHF is a government-sponsored nationwide network consisting of infrastructure and scientific projects dedicated to improvement in efficiency and efficacy of research in HF, quality of care for HF patients, and public education. 13

The Central Biomaterial Bank is a project of the CNHF that provides a central facility to collect all biomaterial from each patient enrolled in one of the network's clinical trials for the purposes of several ongoing and future scientific projects. 14,15

By using the CNHF database (n = ~12 000), we identified all patients with clinical signs of HF and documented SD (LVEF <50%; n = 1046) measured by echocardiography at the respective time of study inclusion (see Supporting Information, Table 3, in the online version of this article).
All diagnostic procedures within the CNHF, including echocardiography, were performed by trained personnel according to standard operating procedures based on international guidelines.
The CNHF mandates the acquisition of a dedicated harmonized clinical dataset for its clinical projects.
All information including medical history, physical examination, electrocardiography, echocardiography, and patient questionnaires was collected using predefined standard operating procedures. 16,17
We defined chronic kidney disease by glomerular filtration rate of ≤30 mL/min.
Serial echocardiography was performed using a prespecified protocol by experienced sonographers in accordance with the recommendations of the American Society of Echocardiography.
LVEF was determined from the apical 2-and 4chamber view using the Simpson biplane method; or, if that was not feasible, the Simpson monoplane method was used.

The left ventricular (LV) end-diastolic diameter was measured from the left parasternal long-axis view at the level of the mitral chordae with the ultrasound beam directed perpendicularly to the LV endocardial surfaces.
An LVEF ≤35% was accepted as an indicator for severe SD, whereas the remaining subjects were considered nonsevere SD (ie, LVEF 36%-49%).

Similarly, and in accordance with the European consensus statement on the diagnosis of HF with normal LVEF by the Heart Failure and Echocardiography associations of the European Society of Cardiology and recommendations of the American Society of Echocardiography, we studied diastolic function in subgroups of severe DD (E/e 0 ≥15) and nonsevere DD (E/e 0 <15).
The average (septal and lateral) e 0 velocity was used. 11,12
In case of atrial fibrillation, 10 cycles of best-representative E/e 0 were analyzed and averaged. 18

Using these criteria, each patient was categorized into 1 of the following 4 subgroups: nonsevere SD with concomitant nonsevere DD, nonsevere SD with severe DD, severe SD with nonsevere DD, and severe SD with severe DD.
All studies within the CNHF comply with the Declaration of Helsinki.
All protocols were approved by the responsible ethics committees, and all patients gave written informed consent prior to study start.
Continuous variables are expressed as mean (standard deviation) and categorical variables described by numbers and percentages.
Means of continuous variables were compared by t test for independent samples.
Categorical variables were tested by the χ 2 test or Fisher exact test, as appropriate.
Duration of HF was classified as ≤ and >5 years.
Hospital length of stay was considered the cumulative number of days spent in hospital over the observation period and was compared by Mann-Whitney U test.
Time-to-event data were depicted by Kaplan-Meier curves and compared by log-rank test.
Age-and sex-adjusted hazard ratios (HRs) with corresponding 95% confidence intervals (CIs) were calculated by Cox proportional hazard regression analysis.

Looking for variables possibly associated with the endpoints of death, cardiac death, and a composite of all-cause and cardiovascular (CV) hospitalization and death, respectively, we built multiple Cox regression models.
From a total of 20 risk factors and comorbidities, a subset was selected by the LASSO method (least absolute selection and shrinkage operator), 19

Included into this analysis were 1046 patients from the database of the CNHF with an LVEF of <50% participating in 3 different clinical followup studies (see Supporting Information, Table 3, in the online version of this article).
The mean age of the study participants was 70 years, 26% were female, and 85% suffered from HF of New York Heart Association functional class II or III.
Out of these patients, 546 (52%) demonstrated nonsevere SD and 500 (48%) severe SD.
Regarding DD, 693 (66%) patients demonstrated nonsevere DD and 353 (34%) patients showed severe DD (see Supporting Information, Table 4, in the online version of this article).

For baseline characteristics of study patients stratified by their echocardiographically determined systolic and diastolic functional status (see Supporting Information, Table 5, in the online version of this article).
Patients with nonsevere SD presented a mean LVEF of 42%, as compared with a mean LVEF of 28% in patients with severe SD (P < 0.001).
No differences in LVEF were evident between the patient groups with nonsevere and severe DD.
Moreover, 37% of patients with nonsevere DD demonstrated an E/e 0 ≤8.

div.head: | Complementary prognostic information of SD and DD

p.s: In the overall population, severe DD (vs nonsevere DD) was significantly associated with the combined endpoint of cardiac death and CV hospitalization even after adjustment for age and sex (HR: 2.01, 95% CI: 1.52-2.66,
Severe SD was associated with higher hazards for all endpoints.
Furthermore, we observed a strong interaction subgroup effect for SD and DD: In patients with nonsevere SD, additional severe DD resulted in a markedly higher risk (HR: 1.73, 95% CI 1.16-2.60,
P = 0.007 for all-cause mortality; HR: 1.82, 95% CI: 0.97-3.42,
P = 0.061 for cardiac mortality; and HR: 1.42, 95% CI: 0.98-2.08,
P = 0.067 for cardiac death and CV hospitalization).
By contrast, in patients with severe SD, additional presence of severe DD added little or no risk.
Patients with severe SD had a 2.5-fold risk of death compared with patients with nonsevere SD (HR: 2.53, 95% CI: 1.84-3.47,
Likewise, severe DD was associated with a higher mortality risk (HR:
P = 0.004), but the risk increase was smaller than in patients with severe SD.
Size and direction of the interaction term SD*DD (HR: 0.63, 95% CI: 0.38-1.05,
P = 0.073) indicated that the mortality risk for patients with severe SD plus severe DD was not as high as might have been expected from a fully additive risk increase of both single risks combined.
Considerable risk was attributable to age alone.
As such, the risk increase (HR: 1.78) conferred by an increment in age by 10 years of similar magnitude as the risk conferred by concomitant severe DD.
Females demonstrated lower mortality than males, but this effect was not significant (Figure 1, Table 1).

Especially with respect to all-cause mortality, we observed a strong interaction effect for SD and DD in that in patients with only moderate SD, severe DD increased risk substantially (HR: 1.73, 95% CI: 1.16-2.6,
Risk of cardiac death for severe SD and severe DD patients was even higher than risk of overall death (severe SD: HR: 3.51, 95% CI: 2.19-5.64,
P = 0.055) and the interaction effect was even slightly more pronounced (HR: 0.53, 95% CI: 0.25-1.13,
Age was also a significant predictor of cardiac death (HR: 1.63 per decade, 95% CI: 1.30-2.04,
P < 0.001); however, a risk difference between females and males could not be shown.
Additionally, unadjusted analysis gave similar results with respect to SD and DD.

Severe SD, as opposed to nonsevere SD, was associated with a nearly doubled risk for cardiac death or CV hospitalization, whereas no impact of severe DD could be shown in these patients with at least moderate SD.
Neither age nor sex had predictive utility in these analyses (age: HR: 0.93, 95% CI: 0.81-1.06,
P = 0.170; Figure 2, Table 1).

The length of hospital stay for both all-cause and CV hospitalizations strongly depended on the severity of SD, whereas severity of DD was irrelevant in patients with both nonsevere or severe SD (Table 2).
We built multiple models for 2 purposes: (1) to adjust for possible confounders (e.g., age and sex), and (2) to search for CV risk factors and comorbidities associated with clinical endpoints.
As expected, the impact of severe SD was not substantially weakened by adjustment by confounding factors.
The effect of DD vanished after inclusion of other risk factors.
Nevertheless, a sizeable interaction effect remained.
Syncope in medical history, malignancy, and hyperuricemia were the variables with the strongest predictive potential (all HR >2; all P < 0.001).
Severe SD, ex-smoker, anemia, female sex, and low body mass index were further identified as significant factors.
In these multiple models, risks of age, hyperlipidemia, duration of HF, and the interaction term SD*DD were rather weak and nonsignificant factors (Table 1 and Figure 3).
Adjusting for atrial fibrillation did not alter the results of multiple models.
The present study investigated in a large cohort of patients with SD the incremental impact of DD on hard clinical endpoints.

Our analyses demonstrated that the degree of SD was the dominant prognostic driver in these patients, but DD had a major modifying effect, rendering it an important research issue and potential therapeutic target.

Our findings are consistent with but extend previous reports such as the Heart Failure and a Controlled Trial Investigating Outcomes of Exercise Training (HF-ACTION) trial and a few smaller studies. 21,22
Because patients with SD were investigated, we focus in the discussion below on the differential prognostic utility of DD in SD.
We observed that DD had a more pronounced impact on prognosis in patients with nonsevere SD compared with severe SD.
This may appear intuitive, because it is more difficult to demonstrate a risk increase in patients already at high risk.

Further, in severe SD, pathophysiological processes may well overlap with those responsible for DD, although is still unclear whether a severely compromised LVEF always represents the common final pathway of aggravated SD and DD. 23,24
tients exhibiting nonsevere SD in combination with severe DD represent an interesting subgroup that may contain patients with "cryptic HFpEF".

It is known that increased ventricular stiffness is associated with systolic abnormalities (ie, it could be demonstrated that cardiac output and contractile response are often blunted during exercise in HFpEF patients despite a preserved or only mildly reduced systolic function at rest).
Such blunted contractile response has been shown to strongly associate with an impaired exercise tolerance. 23,25

Mechanical cardiac dyssynchrony may contribute to the progression of SD because systolic longitudinal strain is conceived particularly low in patients with HFpEF at rest and fails to increase during exercise. 26
Such failing response in longitudinal strain increase in patients with HFpEF may very well be a precursor of a reduced systolic function. 27

Beyond these mechanisms, a deterioration of systolic longitudinal strain may also be involved in DD. 28 This might explain the fact that additional severe DD indicated a relevant risk increase in our patient group with nonsevere SD.

Motoki and colleagues showed that in patients with chronic systolic HF and a mean LVEF of 26%, worsening of LV global longitudinal strain was associated with a more pronounced LV DD and both right ventricular (RV) SD and DD, and provided incremental prognostic value over and above LVEF. 29
e method of choice to reliably assess diastolic function in patients with compromised LVEF is still under debate.

The E/e 0 ratio seems to perform reasonably well in subjects at risk for or with mild cardiac disease but may have limited value in subjects with severe SD, most likely due to concomitant hemodynamic and structural changes that may decrease the validity of tissue Doppler measurements. 30,31
By contrast, in a recent study by Cabrera-Schulmeyer et al, the E/e 0 ratio proved useful in the prediction of morbid events Data are presented as median (IQR).
Hospital LOS is modified by the degree of DD and SD in all patients (allcause hospitalization) and patients hospitalized for CV reasons (CV hospitalization).
after noncardiac surgery (ie, less sick patients).
In this study, the mean LVEF was 41% to 47%, and the lowest LVEF was associated with highest E/e 0 . 32
However, in this study no differentiation between nonsevere and severe SD was made.

In a study by Kuijk et al in patients with peripheral arterial disease, the presence of isolated diastolic, systolic, or combined LV dysfunction was independently associated with increased CV mortality risk irrespective of the presence of diabetes mellitus, and patients with combined SD and DD had the worst CV prognosis. 33

Lee et al showed that a decrease of an initially high e 0 /a 0 ratio predicted a more favorable outcome with respect to long-term therapy in clinically stable patients with chronic HF and severe SD. 34 Tang et al demonstrated that in patients with chronic systolic HF and pronounced cardiac remodeling, septal tissue Doppler measurements were more reliable and clinically relevant than lateral measurements in the assessment of DD. 35 In our study, we calculated both ratios, septal and lateral E/e 0 , but neither parameter excelled.
In conclusion, in these studies it could be demonstrated that both parameters provide a very powerful tool for risk stratification. 36,37
It remains to be shown, however, that such complex determination of diastolic function will be used by clinicians in a real-world setting such as ambulatory care. 33,35

rthermore, considering the recent European Society of Cardiology guidelines introducing the concept of HFmrEF (HF with midrange ejection fraction), our investigations become more important, because our data demonstrate a special effect of diastolic dysfunction on myocardial performance in patients with nonsevere SD. 38
The current project addresses a post-hoc research question to a set of prospective datasets collected in a harmonized fashion.
By definition, such a retrospective observational approach cannot determine causation, only association.
However, endpoint phenotypes were collected in a standardized manner across all CNHF projects, thus ensuring comparability of outcomes.
This study was not designed to investigate the validity of the echocardiographic diastolic measurements under circumstances of SD.
As such, no comparison with the reference standard was available (ie, invasive hemodynamic assessment).
Enrollment of patients from various studies within the German CNHF resulted in a heterogeneous patient sample regarding predominant cause of HF and number and severity of comorbidities.
However, because data were acquired with a high degree of cross-study harmonization, we consider our results plausible and generalizable.
In our study we used E/e 0 as a key parameter to establish a threshold between none, none-severe, and severe DD.
The CNHF was initiated in 2003. 13
Since then, the concept of DD and diastolic HF has repeatedly been modified, and no final consensus has been reached.
All studies of the present analysis targeted HF; however, DD was not an inclusion criterion in all studies.
Nonetheless, in all studies, E/A pattern and tissue Doppler were measured in a harmonized fashion.
These parameters are still considered key for the diagnosis of DD and diastolic HF.

With respect to the work by Paulus et al and keeping in mind that E/e 0 approximately mirrors LV wall tension, we decided to use an E/e 0 ≥15 cutoff to establish a threshold between none, nonsevere, and severe DD. 11
The current study demonstrates that the degree of SD dominates prognosis in patients with HFrEF.
However, the echocardiographic evaluation of diastolic function in these patients provides further prognostic information, in particular in subjects with nonsevere SD.
without giving particular consideration to P values.
Variables with nonzero coefficients were included into a final Cox regression model to estimate HR with 95% CI.
Multiple hospitalization was analyzed by means of an Anderson-Gill counting process model 20 including an interaction term SD*DD.
Statistical analysis was performed using SPSS software version 22 (IBM Corp., Armonk, NY).

In addition, LASSO and Anderson-Gill procedure and respective forest plot were generated by means of the R packages coxph, penalized and Hmisc (R Foundation for Statistical Computing, http://www.r-project.org).
All tests were 2-sided at a significance level of 5%.
FIGURE 1 All-cause mortality in patients with HFrEF (Kaplan-Meier plot).
(A) Patients with ns-SD.
(B) Patients with s-SD.
Graphs are stratified by level of DD: E/e 0 <15 (ns-DD) and E/e 0 ≥15 (s-DD).
HRs with 95% CIs are computed from age-and sex-adjusted Cox regression (ns-SD/ns-DD, n = 396; ns-SD/s-DD, n = 150; s-SD/ns-DD, n = 297; s-SD/s-DD, n = 203).
Abbreviations: CI, confidence interval; DD, diastolic dysfunction; HFrEF, heart failure with reduced ejection fraction; HR, hazard ratio; ns, nonsevere; s, severe; SD, systolic dysfunction.
FIGURE 2 Occurrence of CV endpoints in patients with HFrEF (Kaplan-Meier plot).
(A) All-cause death or hospitalization.
(B) CV death or hospitalization.
Graphs are stratified by combinations of type of HF (DD vs SD) and severity (ns vs s).
HRs with 95% CIs are shown for selected group comparisons and were computed from age-and sex-adjusted Cox regression.

Abbreviations: CI, confidence interval; CV, cardiovascular; DD, diastolic dysfunction; HF, heart failure; HFrEF, heart failure and reduced ejection fraction; HR, hazard ratio; ns, nonsevere; s, severe; SD, systolic dysfunction.
FIGURE 3 Risk factors and comorbidities associated with cardiac death or cardiovascular hospitalization.
Abbreviations: BMI, body mass index; CI, confidence interval; DD, diastolic dysfunction; SD, systolic dysfunction.
Meluzin and colleagues could show that the detailed assessment of RV systolic and diastolic function provided complementary prognostic information in patients with HF.

In these studies, Meluzin and coworkers investigated a systolic and a diastolic parameter of RV function, the peak systolic tricuspid annular velocity, and peak early diastolic tricuspid annular velocity for prognosis of patients with HF.
The authors categorized patients into 4 groups with different constellations of the parameters demonstrated above and with different risk of cardiac events and death.
Covariates associated with clinical endpoints
Abbreviations: CI, confidence interval; CV, cardiovascular; DD, diastolic dysfunction; HR, hazard ratio; LVEF, left ventricular ejection fraction; SD, systolic dysfunction.
Comparison of median hospital LOS
Abbreviations: CV, cardiovascular; DD, diastolic dysfunction; IQR, interquartile range; LOS, length of stay; SD, systolic dysfunction.
The authors declare no potential conflicts of interest.
Additional Supporting Information may be found online in the supporting information tab for this article.
